results.title: My life as I live it
results.creator_credit: Kit Guyatt, Martha Ansara, Essie Coffey and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Essie Coffey’s first film, MY SURVIVAL AS AN ABORIGINAL (1978), is now a classic. It introduced us to the life of her family and her community in far northwest New South Wales. Essie’s new film returns to her home in Dodge City where Essie and the A-Team are nominating for the local Shire Elections. Cutting from people and conditions in the present to the same people and places of the past, we see that some things have changed and some have stayed the same. The racism is still there, but the CDEP (Community Development Employment Program) has brought a new pride and hope for the future. In place of the arrests on pension day, there is now police-community liaison and the hope that the tragedies like the death in custody of Essie’s nephew Lloyd Boney will not happen again. We hear testimony about Lloyd’s death from CDEP supervisor, Dallas Skuthorpe, a young participant in the earlier film. We meet up again with other kids from the 1978 film too - some now with families of their own, and involved in education, art, and sports; or still trying to overcome the personal effects of what happened in the past. Throughout the film, we share the lively thoughts and presence of Essie herself, popularly known as Bush Queen, as always, “a fighter and a voice of her people”. This portrait of an Aboriginal community working towards self-determination is a testament to Essie’s life.

results.title: Round up (A)
results.creator_credit: Rima Tamou, Pauline Clague and Core Original Productions
results.brief_description: Two country boys, one white and the other aboriginal find themselves out of place in the hustle and bustle of the big city. What they learn on the journey that they embark upon through unfamiliar territory, is that they are not as different as they first thought.

results.title: Fly Peewee fly (A)
results.creator_credit: Sally Riley, Adrienne Parr, SBS Independent and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A young Aboriginal boy, Robbie is in the midst of the conflict between his father and his grandmother. Robbie’s grandmother is white and wants to give Robbie every advantage, while Robbie’s aboriginal father is searching for his own identity and place. A warm story about fragile but meaningful family relationships.

results.title: Songlines: contemporary aboriginal music (A)
results.creator_credit: Richard Frankland, John Foss, Australian Contemporary Music Development Co (AUSMUSIC) and Golden Seahorse Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic music industry skills”.
Introduction to the Music Industry. Module 4.6. Contemporary Australian Aboriginal music has become an international presence in recent years. This program profiles artists who have taken their brand of indigenous music to the world: Yothu Yindi, Archie Roach and Tiddas. Traditional elements are incorporated into contemporary styles. This is not simply a matter of throwing in the odd didjeridu and clap stick, but rather the traditional cultural role of Aboriginal music as an educational medium is maintained and extended to cover new, important issues and themes.

results.title: From sand to celluloid (A)
results.creator_credit: Bill McCrow, Warwick Thornton, Darlene Johnson, Rima Tamou, Sally Riley, Richard Frankland, Franco Di Chiera, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: An impressive collection of Australian short films by Indigenous filmmakers which explore the history and contradictions of Aboriginal identity. Richard Frankland’s “No Way to Forget” is the story of a young man, working on the Royal Commission on Black Deaths in Custody, who drives home to Melbourne and is haunted by the ghosts of the dead. dead. In Sally Riley’s “Fly Peewee Fly!”, a young boy teaches his white grandmother and his Koorie father a few lessons on perspective. Rima Tamou’s “Round Up” is a tender story about two country boys who discover that their racial differences are not so acute when they are confronted with the multiculturalism and subcultures of the inner-city. In “Two Bob Mermaid” Darlene Johnson presents a beautifully filmed story about a young girl who can pass for white in a racially divided 1957 Australia. Warwick Thornton’s “Payback” presents a surreal story of a young convict who has to obey tribal lore as much as he does white law. Bill McCrow’s “Black Man Down” explores the need for contemporary Aborigines to be aware of the lessons and spirituality of the past.

results.title: When dreaming paths meet (A)
results.creator_credit: Richard Frankland, John Foss, Australia. Dept. of Health, Housing and Community Services and Golden Seahorse Productions
results.brief_description: This program aims to promote Cross-Cultural Awareness and explores situations in which the actions of Aboriginal people have been misinterpreted by non-Aboriginal people in a work environment. Three scenarios highlight body language differences in a youth custody situation, bereavement issues and community relations. At the conclusion of each scene, Richard Frankland summarises and discusses pro-active measures that can be implemented to prevent such Cross-Cultural problems occurring in the future. Designed to be used by non-Aboriginal professionals to promote an understanding of cultural issues.

results.title: BeDevil
results.creator_credit: Tracey Moffatt, Carol Hughes, Anthony Buckley and Southern Star Entertainment
results.brief_description: BeDevil is an astounding work of Australian cinema which combines iconography drawn from Aboriginal culture and mythology, urban Australia, and popular culture. Comprising three ghost stories, all of which deal with the nature of memory and loss, this film playfully subverts the conventional linkings between aboriginality and spirituality. In “Mr. Chuck” the ghost of a US soldier haunts a billabong. In “Choo Choo Choo Choo” Ruby, (played by director Tracey Moffatt), and her family are haunted by an invisible train. In the final story, “Lovin’ The Spin I’m In”, a grieving Islander mother and her Greek-Australian neighbours are under the spell of the ghostly lovers, Bebe and Minnie. Drawing from influences that span across Aboriginal culture, American and European film, television and popular culture, “BeDevil” announces the birth of a new kind of Australian cinema: both indigenous and multicultural; mystical and sophisticated; innovative and pleasurable. The intoxicating cinematography is by Academy-award winning Geoff Burton and the music score is by Carl Vine. Visually stunning and metaphorically rich, this is a wonderful film.

results.title: Poison
results.brief_description: This drama, the first ever to come out of the ABC’s ‘Blackout’ series, considers three major aspects of Aboriginal reality - assimilation, adoption and sexual abuse, and how these circumstances have prompted the addictive personalities. It is the ugly, yet surprisingly beautiful, story of four troubled young people living together in a city squat. Although this film is about Aboriginal people, it is essentially about people in general - their anguish, their pain and their need to be loved and accepted. The story takes place within 24 hours and begins with languid preparations for a night on the town. Raylene (Lydia Miller), Wayne (Russell Page), Laniece (Rhoda Roberts) and Sharon (Lillian Crombie) stumble their way through a sleazy round of nightspots, becoming increasingly stoned and disoriented. While clinging to the fragile security they provide for each other, each is lost in his or her own private world, trying to contend with a past that keeps rearing its ugly head. ‘Poison’ is a telling tale about the difficulties experienced by so many Aboriginal people in coming to terms with themselves, their past and a society that has wronged them and demonstrates their struggle to cope with life under the cloud.

results.title: Aboriginal bark painting (A)
results.creator_credit: Latrobe University. School of Education. Media Centre
results.brief_description: Made in partnership with the Barinaga Aboriginal Co-operative at Maningrida, Northern Territory. Provides an informative look at the bark paintings of Arnhem Land, placing the art work firmly in the context of Aboriginal belief systems and using traditional techniques. A useful complement to “The art and craft of Maningrida”. Narrated by Robin Cuming.

results.title: In the name of the crow
results.creator_credit: Peter Kordyl, Mark Bin Bakar, Marion Benjamin, Robert Bropho, Heather Williams and Excalibur Nominees
results.brief_description: Most tourists who visit Rottnest Island are unaware of its history. Established as a prison for Aboriginal men around 1840, it was intended as a place for “rehabilitation”. However, accounts of floggings, chainings and hangings flourished on the mainland despite official enquiries and commissions suggesting everything was in order. In this documentary, Robert Bropho takes us to the island and traces the hardship and the suffering of his ancestors that has been omitted from white man’s history.
